sessions.title: Registration and Breakfast
sessions.description: Foyer

sessions.title: CAPES aren't just for super heroes... They're for you too!
sessions.description:
CAPES is an acronym for the top soft skills needed in technology today; Communication/Collaboration, Adaptability, perseverance, Empathy and self-awareness. Because hard skills generally create revenue, we hire individuals based on their technical skills but we fail for identify how the lack of soft skill can negatively impact the company's ledger. 
This 50 minute session will define the 5 soft skills most prominent in technology today, detail the pros and cons of soft skills in the workplace, list ways that soft skills can help you in your career and identify ways we can improve these skills in our everyday lives.

sessions.title: Morning Break
Brick by Brick: What Lego Taught Me About Great APIs
sessions.description: It had been over a decade since I put together a Lego set. But a recent gift changed everything and I quickly found myself captivated building a new Lego model. As I went, I realized so many of the wonderful things that make Lego amazing apply beyond the boundaries of plastic brick building. They apply directly to all kinds of APIs! Join me as we delve into the Lego building experience and the lessons we can learn along the way to make our APIs Lego-level great.

sessions.title: Add Interactive Live Video to Your Application with Amazon IVS
sessions.description: In this session, we'll look at how you can use Amazon Interactive Video Service (IVS) to add live, interactive video streaming to your application with the IVS JavaScript SDK. In the first 5 months of 2022, users consumed over 543 billion minutes of live video created by almost 9 million creators on Twitch. There's no question that streaming is popular, but why is it so in-demand? Part of the draw for users is that streaming is unscripted, dynamic, and unpredictable. It's not the same old formulaic "cookie-cutter" content available via traditional mediums. Another attraction is the high level of interactivity with the content producer. What other medium provides live chat and interaction to viewers while they consume the content? Streaming gives the consumer a level of active participation in their entertainment instead of just passively consuming it. It's also highly accessible - anyone can set up a stream at little to no cost from the comfort of their own home or office - or anywhere as long as they have a modern mobile device and internet connectivity. But it's not just for video games - any application that needs to reach an audience can take advantage of the power of streaming to reach millions of users!

sessions.title: Lunch and Panel
Future of the Web Fireside Chat
sessions.description: Join for a conversation about future front end trends

sessions.title: Scaling your Frontend Engineering System
sessions.description: Building an engineering system used by ten engineers is hard. Building an engineering system used by 1,000 engineers is also hard! This talk will cover real world scenarios of when an engineering system needs to be scaled to support millions of lines of code, dozens of teams, and thousands of engineeers.

sessions.title: The Command Line - A Humble Journey
sessions.description:
Have you used the command line lately? Ever given much thought to how it came to be?

I'm not surprised - I haven't given it much thought either. But after learning more about the journey the CLI has taken to get us to where we are today, gives me a new appreciation, and understanding, of how the CLI works. Many of the things we do today are rooted in the past, and the CLI is no different. Sit back, relax, and enjoy the origin story of our old friend, the command line.

sessions.title: Afternoon Break
Use the Platform with Framework-Agnostic Routing
sessions.description:
Have you ever had to code logic for navigations, loading/mutating/reloading data, or request cancellations in your apps? Have you ever gotten it wrong? Let me show you a future where you can let the new Remix Router handle all of that for you - all while coding in the UI library of your choosing.

At Remix we're _stoked_ about nested + data-driven routing. The `loaders`/`actions` approach pioneered by the Remix framework has completely changed how we think about writing our applications. The days of render-driven waterfall data loads -- and all the spinners that come with it -- are over, and the resulting UX/DX is amazing. We're so excited about this approach that we didn't think it was fair to keep this limited to the React ecosystem. We realized early on that this was a Web (not React) problem that needed a Web (not React) solution

Let's walk through some of the problems with modern render/fetch-in-component approaches and look at how we can provide a much better experience for our users if we change the way we think about our application architecture. We'll look at the benefits of nested and data-driven routing, and the new framework-agnostic Remix Router driving React Router 6.4.0. We'll show how this router _vastly_ simplifies our mental model and reduces our application code, leading to better user experiences and fewer bugs! We gain this simplicity by embracing web standards and using things the browser already does _really_ well -- like handling forms, requests, and responses -- all while keeping the awesome UX provided by today's modern frameworks.

Finally, we'll look at how we can leverage the Remix Router in frameworks beyond React. You'll be amazed at how much framework-specific code disappears when you're delegating the majority of your routing, loading, and mutating logic to the Remix Router. Say goodbye to all those `useState/useEffects` (React) or those `ref/watchEffects` (Vue) and focus on writing your presentation layer in the library of your choice. So whether you're rocking with React, vibing with Vue, or all about that Angular - you can leverage the Remix Router to provide great experiences for your users.

sessions.title: The 7 Pillar Developer: Lifestyle Systems for the Exceptional Developer
sessions.description: To dramatically expand our potential as developers, we must reconsider our behaviors away from the keyboard, as humans. In this story-oriented session, we'll explore seven surprisingly relevant facets of life that profoundly impact our software quality: focus, systems thinking, psychology, communication, image, time management, and education.

sessions.title: Team Trivia and Conf reception!
sessions.description: Team Trivia and Conf reception!

sessions.title: TypeScript + React = ❤️
sessions.description:
TypeScript is a JavaScript superset that compiles down to vanilla JavaScript and has become increasingly popular. TypeScript proponents proclaim that it eliminates entire classes of bugs that affect our applications. But what exactly are those bugs? Which ones are particular to building React components and applications? Is TypeScript even worth the learning curve?

In this session geared towards devs with prior experience building React applications, let’s answer those questions. We’ll walk through the common bugs that infect our apps and learn how the use of strong types with TypeScript can help prevent them. After the session, you’ll be itching to try it out in your next project!

sessions.title: Picking a React Framework in 2022
sessions.description: Sure, there's create-react-app. But in 2022, there's a compelling selection of robust React frameworks to consider. In this session, we'll explore the merits and tradeoffs of the top contenders including Next, Remix, Gatsby, Redwood, and various "React-like" alternatives. After this session, you'll have a clear understanding of whether a specific full framework is a good fit for your next project.

sessions.title: Declarative Fetching Libraries
sessions.description: A deep dive into React Query, Apollo Client and SWR. The talk will walk through the setup, the pros, and the cons of each of these fetching libraries. Dive deep to look at the differences on how these libraries each affect data management and state in a React Application with GraphQL.

sessions.title: React Server Components with non-JS backends
sessions.description:
React Server Components are an exciting upcoming feature that makes it easy to deliver a faster and better web experience for your users. However, with the shift of React to the server, companies not already using Node.js on the backend may shy away from this technology and thus lose out on any of the benefits it brings.

But it is as not as difficult as it seems! In this presentation, I will show how you can use tools such as containers and code generation to make it easy for server components to interface with your backend of choice during both development and deployment.

sessions.title: AI in React.js
sessions.description: Want to see how easy it is to build a website with React?  Let's create a few websites live!  You'll understand the basics of AI, and more importantly you'll see how easy it is to come up with new ideas that have never been done before, and build them.  This talk is the comic book transformation from React developer to superhero.

sessions.title: Migrating from Vue CLI to Vite
sessions.description:
Vite has revolutionized the Vue.js development experience with it's lightning fast server starts and HMR. It's the definite first pick for starting up any new project. But what about your existing projects that use Vue CLI? Vue CLI projects can be migrated to use Vite to capitalize on that awesome developer experience. Learn the steps to get it done!

For those who haven't used Vite yet, during the talk we'll briefly look at what Vite is and a little about how it works. Afterwards, we'll walk through the 9 common steps it takes to move from a Vue CLI powered project to Vite. While the 9 steps discussed probably won't take your larger projects 100% of the way, they are a great starting point.

sessions.title: What is a Vue Component?
sessions.description:
Pretty much anything smaller than a whole application can be considered a "component", but when we want to talk about them with other people, it can help to be more specific.

In this talk let's use examples and try to separate out (and name) different kinds of components based on their role in an application in the designs we are building with Vue. We'll start with a basic component and work our way up, taking some time along the way to talk about props, slots, and the component lifecycle.

Spotting patterns in how we use components can help us understand our front-end architecture and testing needs, find some language that we can use when talking with designers and other stakeholders about "components" as they see them, and be more clear when communicating with other developers in our own team about the actual Vue components that implement a given design.

sessions.title: Create a Custom Component Library with Vue3 and Tailwind CSS!
sessions.description: This talk will include a step by step guide on how to setup your own custom component library published to NPM with the Vue3 and Tailwind CSS.

sessions.title: Compose yourself! Different kinds of composition functions
sessions.description:
Composables can be simple or complex. They can be as simple as a logic gate or as complex as any renderless component, mixin, directive, or plugin.

From "useTimeout" to "useVirtualList", VueUse provides a collection of essential composition functions and renderless components.

In this session, we'll take a deep-dive into VueUse.

sessions.title: If it ain’t broke, why fix it? AKA Migrating from $FRAMEWORK to Vue
sessions.description: The phrase “if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it” is something many of us have heard, especially when dealing with “legacy code.” In this talk, Kayla will talk about her experiences with moving a codebase from KnockoutJS to Vue. She’ll discuss the process of refactoring an application to modern JavaScript framework and potential strategies to mitigate technical debt along the way. She’ll also give you some talking points to help convince your boss to take development time away from adding new features to focus on upgrading the tech stack to something that’s easier to work with. Because if it ain’t broke, why should we fix it?

sessions.title: Delighting users with performant apps
sessions.description:
Ok, so you want to build an app that can be fast, performant, and keep your users coming back for more? Think you need to reach for native? Think again! The Web is an amazing platform that offers developers a lot of ways to build amazing experiences. The only problem is...it requires some tricks to get the experience to not be terrible. So, if native is so great at performance, how can we make the web compete?

Let's take a look at an app that comes with every iOS device and see what features set it apart from your standard web app. Then, with a minimal rebuild of this app, we'll add UX details that are not only performant, but also make user want to use your app.

sessions.title: Svelte - a shortcut to a11y?
sessions.description: Svelte has been described as an “accessibility-first-framework”, yet its compiler warnings cover only a fragment of the issues at hand. In this talk, I’d like to explore how accessible Svelte really is and more importantly, have a look at what you can do to bridge the gap. Ideas include checking both automatically and manually for issues the compiler might overlook, like color contrast, keyboard accessibility and semantics.

sessions.title: Engineering + Management != "Engineering Management"
sessions.description:
This and other oops! and aha!'s I discovered as I transitioned from an Engineer to an Engineering Manager

Great engineers don't necessarily make great engineering managers. If you are currently an engineer / tech lead and thinking about switching to an engineering  manager role, you may have several questions. You may be wondering if it’s the right move and if you have the right skills to succeed. Having made the transition a couple years ago, I can say I went through a steeper learning curve than I imagined. In this talk I will share some of the things I had to learn, and more importantly things I had to unlearn to be successful at engineering management.

sessions.title: The Future of Front End Tooling is Here: Esbuild, Vite, Turbopack & Webpack
sessions.description: The front end build tooling landscape is changing rapidly.  Let's take a look at the new available technologies, and how they operate.  Then, we'll dive into migration concerns and even talk about leveraging some of this new tech within existing Webpack projects!

sessions.title: Accelerating Multi-tenant Full Stack Development with AWS Amplify
sessions.description: Learn how AWS Amplify can enable rapid development of React based full stack SaaS Application that enable the management and isolation of tenant users, a GraphQL integration with functions as a services, and options for NoSQL and Relational database storage.

sessions.title: TBD
Data Metamorphosis With KafkaJS
sessions.description: As you enter the world of microservices, you will need a way to have easy communication across your containers. As a JavaScript developer, you might be tempted to use REST APIs across the board. Express is certainly a familiar framework, but it might now be the best choice. Enter KafkaJS. Using Kafka is a tool to ensure fluid communication across all of your microservices. To implement it with your JavaScript applications, you can use KafkaJS. In this talk, the attendees will learn how to use Kafka in the context of a JavaScript microservices architecture.

sessions.title: Dungeons, Dragons, and Graph Databases
sessions.description:
Are you an adventurer? Do you want gold? Experience? Levels? Of course you do! And where do you get these things? The dungeon, where else? That wonderful container of all things adventurous! But, unfortunately, dungeons aren't setup for the convenience of adventurers who wish to extract these fine things. It’s almost as if the dungeon master just made the dungeon up at random. And so you wander about and you get what you get.

But you’re also a developer. You could build a database of all the rooms with their shiny and monstrous content. Then you could query it and find the optimal route to get the gold and the experience and the levels. But how would you model this data and write these queries? The rooms. The corridors. The monsters. The sparkling hoozits. That’s a lot of entities to relate to each other. And that’s gonna be a monster of a SQL query. Whoa–look at that JOIN! Better get my text editor ready.

Or, you could use a graph database. A graph database allows you to model these relationships simply and intuitively with nodes and edges. Being schema-free, you can evolve your graph as you encounter new things such as traps or secret doors. And, using the Cypher query language, you can write elegant and easy to understand queries that find the best routes to get the stuff adventures desire most.

In this talk, I’ll use the aforementioned example to introduce you to the concepts of graph databases. I’ll compare how to solve this problem with a relational database and how a graph database makes it easier. I’ll show you how to query and modify your graph. And, as no talk would be complete without a live demo, I’ll do it all using a real-time procedurally generated random dungeon (I am a dungeon master after all).

So come, have a flagon of mead as you learn about graph databases, optimize your dungeon crawl, and equip another weapon in your quest for better software!

sessions.title: Why GraphQL is Perfect for Node.js Microservices
sessions.description: GraphQL and microservices architectures are perfectly compatible. You can use GraphQL as a data layer for Node.js microservices and combine data from all these services into one universal API. This way, you can break the core of your services into different microservices while still providing one endpoint that your clients can interact with. Before diving into GraphQL, let's explore what microservices are and why it can be helpful to add GraphQL.

sessions.title: What You Need to Know About the Edge
sessions.description: If you listen to the hype, everything is moving to the "edge!" First we started deploying our apps and assets there and now our functions are moving there and even our data is migrating there - all powered by JavaScript. If you're wondering how the edge applies to you and your app, this session will break it down. We'll cover what we mean by the edge and specific ways you can leverage edge functions and edge data to improve your application.

sessions.title: Accessibility as a Process
sessions.description:
Your project isn't ADA compliant, now what? Where do you even begin to apply the information in the WCAG? This talk will help explain the sections of the WCAG and how to include accessibility your project plans.

The WCAG provides a great deal of information to help companies build accessible projects on the web. But it's not uncommon for those who try to navigate its content to become overwhelmed. This can lead to task paralysis making it difficult to take the next steps towards fixing the issues with your project. This talk will highlight a few common accessibility issues and how to use the various sections of the WCAG and RACI to help establish a way forward. Allowing you to move forward with building a better, more inclusive product.

sessions.title: Accessibility Overlays: Why You Should Avoid Them.
sessions.description:
More and more these days "accessibility" overlays are taking over the Web landscape. The impact of these is far-reaching and the marketing behind it drives the overlay space as more and more unsuspecting companies and organizations sign contracts with these unscrupulous overlay vendors and get duped into thinking that an overlay will fix all their accessibility issues. In fact, they are more and more prevalent daily. 

I will go into what overlays are, why they create more barriers than they do remove them, and explain to the audience why they are harmful to the disabled community and what to do when you come across an overlay and how to fight back and make the Web more accessible by taking these overlays down.

sessions.title: Web for all. The power of progressive web apps
sessions.description: As web performance and user experience across both mobile and desktop devices continue to increase in importance, so do progressive web apps (PWAs). PWAs are becoming more popular because they have lots of enhancements that help your application perform better and they make apps accessible even to users with limited internet connection. In this talk, you are going to learn the advantages of using PWAs and how to turn your web application into a PWA.

sessions.title: Deceptive Patterns & FAST
sessions.description:
Deceptive patterns (also widely known as "dark patterns") are all over the Web. I'll speak to the accessibility impact deceptive patterns and "dark" patterns have as well as my introduction to taking these patterns and my work in the W3C to have these published in WCAG 3.

There is a lot of work being done in the Functional Needs group of the W3C to introduce these to FAST. I'll talk about FAST, what it means to accessibility, and to users, developers, designers, and everyone in-between in the organization.

I'll also introduce people to the Framework for Accessible Specification of Technologies (FAST) which advises creators of technical specifications on ensuring their technology meets the needs of users with disabilities. It primarily addresses web content technologies but also relates to any technology that affects web content sent to users, including client-side APIs, transmission protocols, and interchange formats. Specifications that implement these guidelines make it possible for content authors and user agents to render the content in an accessible manner to people with a wide range of abilities.

sessions.title: Pixel-Perfect Mockups and Other Disasters
sessions.description:
Designers and developers are both integral parts of delivering a functional software product. So why does it often feel like pulling teeth when the two need to cross paths? In this talk, I’ll dive into common pitfalls in the design to delivery hand-off, and why this really isn’t a hand-off at all.   

We’ll discuss why things like pixel-perfect mockups and separate design and development phases make the process harder than it needs to be. We'll also discuss why practices like the design sandwich and designer-developer pairing sessions lead to both better and faster results.

sessions.title: Using Kendo UI in your Angular Apps
sessions.description: Kendo UI is a wonderful component library, built specifically in Angular for Angular apps! It includes over 70 professional UI components that are fully accessible, easily integrated into existing design systems, and are backed by legendary technical support. Come to this session to get into some of the awesome features of the Kendo UI Components!

sessions.title: Content projection for truly generic Angular components
sessions.description: In this talk, Alain is going to introduce simple methods to make presentation components not so dumb anymore. Using content projection and quite a few syntax tricks, we will see how we can build components that can be used in multiple different contexts, offer a lot of customization options, and have an easy-to-understand API.

sessions.title: Look Out, Redux! Here Comes NGXS!
sessions.description: NGXS brings Redux-like state management to Angular, but takes advantage of TypeScript to reduce the amount of boilerplate a programmer has to write. This session will introduce NGXS and its features, explain how it differs from Redux and why one might use it, followed by a look at a sample program. The speaker will provide some hints about using and debugging NGXS in the real world that were learned from using it at a project at a Fortune 500 company.

sessions.title: Progressive state management with Angular
sessions.description:
You’ve probably heard about NgRx, Redux, and other options for state management with Angular. Perhaps you considered those solutions but steered away from them because of the extra complexity and volume of code introduced by NgRx and Redux.
In this talk, Alain is going to explain the basics of how to manage your application state with Angular, as well as cover a more progressive approach to state management.
We will be talking about RxJs, Subjects, Observable Stores, and get into Ngrx Store as the ultimate step in our state management journey.

sessions.title: TBD
Browser APIs You Should Know But Probably Don't
sessions.description: You might be familiar with some of the most common browser APIs, like localStorage or fetch. However, there are a ton of lesser known APIs that do incredible things. Do you know how the picture-in-picture API works or what the Beacon API is? Come to this talk and we'll dive into those APIs and others that you can use today, but probably didn't think to.

sessions.title: Shared web workers -- A new way to manage token refresh requests
sessions.description: Utilizing shared web workers for refresh token management in a  multiple-tab SPA scenario

sessions.title: Using Chrome Developer Tools
sessions.description:
Chrome is not just a great browser for viewing websites, but also an invaluable tool for building websites. Out of the box, Chrome ships with “developers tools”. Many web developers are aware of this and make use of some of the tools it provides. However, most developers only scratch the surface of what the browser can do.

Join in as we take a deep dive into the Chrome developer tools and learn, among other things, how to:

– Quickly test styling fixes
– Emulate handheld devices to test responsive designs
– Easily navigate and debug JavaScript
– Use the JavaScript console
– View form submissions
– Monitor AJAX requests
– Check for performance issues
– Troubleshoot caching issues
– Create and use your own snippets

sessions.title: What does it takes to make a div?
sessions.description:
With the advent of frameworks, build tools, and deployment services, the distance between developers and browsers is growing. Developer Experience has improved, but with these abstractions, we've introduced layers of obscurity.

In this talk, we'll take a deep dive into what happens after you hit save. What processes take place to get your code transformed for production, how does it get deployed, and the steps required before a div can get to a user.

sessions.title: Common Accessibility Pitfalls: Climbing out, when you fall in.
sessions.description:
You, your users, and Alice from Wonderland have something in common. At one point, everyone has fallen into a hole of perplexity, confusion, and sometimes hysterical madness. Unlike Alice, we can navigate ourselves and our users around the chaotic abyss that we call the web. Shipping inaccessible experiences to our users can have unpleasant effects. Being cognizant of all the things that can go wrong and who are potential users are will take us farther along our journey.

In this session we are going to learn about common accessibility violations that surface when we are lackadaisical about the experiences we ship. We will cover semantic markup, alt attributes and images, color contrast, and more. Attendees will walk away able to identify these problem areas in their codebases and learning techniques, tools, and best practices to keep our users happy and not drive them mad.

session.title: Registration and Breakfast
session.description: Foyer

session.title: CAPES aren't just for super heroes... They're for you too!
session.description:
CAPES is an acronym for the top soft skills needed in technology today; Communication/Collaboration, Adaptability, perseverance, Empathy and self-awareness. Because hard skills generally create revenue, we hire individuals based on their technical skills but we fail for identify how the lack of soft skill can negatively impact the company's ledger. 
This 50 minute session will define the 5 soft skills most prominent in technology today, detail the pros and cons of soft skills in the workplace, list ways that soft skills can help you in your career and identify ways we can improve these skills in our everyday lives.

session.title: Morning Break
Brick by Brick: What Lego Taught Me About Great APIs
session.description: It had been over a decade since I put together a Lego set. But a recent gift changed everything and I quickly found myself captivated building a new Lego model. As I went, I realized so many of the wonderful things that make Lego amazing apply beyond the boundaries of plastic brick building. They apply directly to all kinds of APIs! Join me as we delve into the Lego building experience and the lessons we can learn along the way to make our APIs Lego-level great.

session.title: TypeScript + React = ❤️
session.description:
TypeScript is a JavaScript superset that compiles down to vanilla JavaScript and has become increasingly popular. TypeScript proponents proclaim that it eliminates entire classes of bugs that affect our applications. But what exactly are those bugs? Which ones are particular to building React components and applications? Is TypeScript even worth the learning curve?

In this session geared towards devs with prior experience building React applications, let’s answer those questions. We’ll walk through the common bugs that infect our apps and learn how the use of strong types with TypeScript can help prevent them. After the session, you’ll be itching to try it out in your next project!

session.title: Migrating from Vue CLI to Vite
session.description:
Vite has revolutionized the Vue.js development experience with it's lightning fast server starts and HMR. It's the definite first pick for starting up any new project. But what about your existing projects that use Vue CLI? Vue CLI projects can be migrated to use Vite to capitalize on that awesome developer experience. Learn the steps to get it done!

For those who haven't used Vite yet, during the talk we'll briefly look at what Vite is and a little about how it works. Afterwards, we'll walk through the 9 common steps it takes to move from a Vue CLI powered project to Vite. While the 9 steps discussed probably won't take your larger projects 100% of the way, they are a great starting point.

session.title: Delighting users with performant apps
session.description:
Ok, so you want to build an app that can be fast, performant, and keep your users coming back for more? Think you need to reach for native? Think again! The Web is an amazing platform that offers developers a lot of ways to build amazing experiences. The only problem is...it requires some tricks to get the experience to not be terrible. So, if native is so great at performance, how can we make the web compete?

Let's take a look at an app that comes with every iOS device and see what features set it apart from your standard web app. Then, with a minimal rebuild of this app, we'll add UX details that are not only performant, but also make user want to use your app.

session.title: TBD
Accessibility as a Process
session.description:
Your project isn't ADA compliant, now what? Where do you even begin to apply the information in the WCAG? This talk will help explain the sections of the WCAG and how to include accessibility your project plans.

The WCAG provides a great deal of information to help companies build accessible projects on the web. But it's not uncommon for those who try to navigate its content to become overwhelmed. This can lead to task paralysis making it difficult to take the next steps towards fixing the issues with your project. This talk will highlight a few common accessibility issues and how to use the various sections of the WCAG and RACI to help establish a way forward. Allowing you to move forward with building a better, more inclusive product.

session.title: Using Kendo UI in your Angular Apps
session.description: Kendo UI is a wonderful component library, built specifically in Angular for Angular apps! It includes over 70 professional UI components that are fully accessible, easily integrated into existing design systems, and are backed by legendary technical support. Come to this session to get into some of the awesome features of the Kendo UI Components!

session.title: Browser APIs You Should Know But Probably Don't
session.description: You might be familiar with some of the most common browser APIs, like localStorage or fetch. However, there are a ton of lesser known APIs that do incredible things. Do you know how the picture-in-picture API works or what the Beacon API is? Come to this talk and we'll dive into those APIs and others that you can use today, but probably didn't think to.

session.title: Add Interactive Live Video to Your Application with Amazon IVS
session.description: In this session, we'll look at how you can use Amazon Interactive Video Service (IVS) to add live, interactive video streaming to your application with the IVS JavaScript SDK. In the first 5 months of 2022, users consumed over 543 billion minutes of live video created by almost 9 million creators on Twitch. There's no question that streaming is popular, but why is it so in-demand? Part of the draw for users is that streaming is unscripted, dynamic, and unpredictable. It's not the same old formulaic "cookie-cutter" content available via traditional mediums. Another attraction is the high level of interactivity with the content producer. What other medium provides live chat and interaction to viewers while they consume the content? Streaming gives the consumer a level of active participation in their entertainment instead of just passively consuming it. It's also highly accessible - anyone can set up a stream at little to no cost from the comfort of their own home or office - or anywhere as long as they have a modern mobile device and internet connectivity. But it's not just for video games - any application that needs to reach an audience can take advantage of the power of streaming to reach millions of users!

session.title: Picking a React Framework in 2022
session.description: Sure, there's create-react-app. But in 2022, there's a compelling selection of robust React frameworks to consider. In this session, we'll explore the merits and tradeoffs of the top contenders including Next, Remix, Gatsby, Redwood, and various "React-like" alternatives. After this session, you'll have a clear understanding of whether a specific full framework is a good fit for your next project.

session.title: What is a Vue Component?
session.description:
Pretty much anything smaller than a whole application can be considered a "component", but when we want to talk about them with other people, it can help to be more specific.

In this talk let's use examples and try to separate out (and name) different kinds of components based on their role in an application in the designs we are building with Vue. We'll start with a basic component and work our way up, taking some time along the way to talk about props, slots, and the component lifecycle.

Spotting patterns in how we use components can help us understand our front-end architecture and testing needs, find some language that we can use when talking with designers and other stakeholders about "components" as they see them, and be more clear when communicating with other developers in our own team about the actual Vue components that implement a given design.

session.title: Svelte - a shortcut to a11y?
session.description: Svelte has been described as an “accessibility-first-framework”, yet its compiler warnings cover only a fragment of the issues at hand. In this talk, I’d like to explore how accessible Svelte really is and more importantly, have a look at what you can do to bridge the gap. Ideas include checking both automatically and manually for issues the compiler might overlook, like color contrast, keyboard accessibility and semantics.

session.title: Data Metamorphosis With KafkaJS
session.description: As you enter the world of microservices, you will need a way to have easy communication across your containers. As a JavaScript developer, you might be tempted to use REST APIs across the board. Express is certainly a familiar framework, but it might now be the best choice. Enter KafkaJS. Using Kafka is a tool to ensure fluid communication across all of your microservices. To implement it with your JavaScript applications, you can use KafkaJS. In this talk, the attendees will learn how to use Kafka in the context of a JavaScript microservices architecture.

session.title: Accessibility Overlays: Why You Should Avoid Them.
session.description:
More and more these days "accessibility" overlays are taking over the Web landscape. The impact of these is far-reaching and the marketing behind it drives the overlay space as more and more unsuspecting companies and organizations sign contracts with these unscrupulous overlay vendors and get duped into thinking that an overlay will fix all their accessibility issues. In fact, they are more and more prevalent daily. 

I will go into what overlays are, why they create more barriers than they do remove them, and explain to the audience why they are harmful to the disabled community and what to do when you come across an overlay and how to fight back and make the Web more accessible by taking these overlays down.

session.title: Content projection for truly generic Angular components
session.description: In this talk, Alain is going to introduce simple methods to make presentation components not so dumb anymore. Using content projection and quite a few syntax tricks, we will see how we can build components that can be used in multiple different contexts, offer a lot of customization options, and have an easy-to-understand API.

session.title: Shared web workers -- A new way to manage token refresh requests
session.description: Utilizing shared web workers for refresh token management in a  multiple-tab SPA scenario

session.title: Lunch and Panel
Future of the Web Fireside Chat
session.description: Join for a conversation about future front end trends

session.title: Scaling your Frontend Engineering System
session.description: Building an engineering system used by ten engineers is hard. Building an engineering system used by 1,000 engineers is also hard! This talk will cover real world scenarios of when an engineering system needs to be scaled to support millions of lines of code, dozens of teams, and thousands of engineeers.

session.title: Declarative Fetching Libraries
session.description: A deep dive into React Query, Apollo Client and SWR. The talk will walk through the setup, the pros, and the cons of each of these fetching libraries. Dive deep to look at the differences on how these libraries each affect data management and state in a React Application with GraphQL.

session.title: Create a Custom Component Library with Vue3 and Tailwind CSS!
session.description: This talk will include a step by step guide on how to setup your own custom component library published to NPM with the Vue3 and Tailwind CSS.

session.title: Engineering + Management != "Engineering Management"
session.description:
This and other oops! and aha!'s I discovered as I transitioned from an Engineer to an Engineering Manager

Great engineers don't necessarily make great engineering managers. If you are currently an engineer / tech lead and thinking about switching to an engineering  manager role, you may have several questions. You may be wondering if it’s the right move and if you have the right skills to succeed. Having made the transition a couple years ago, I can say I went through a steeper learning curve than I imagined. In this talk I will share some of the things I had to learn, and more importantly things I had to unlearn to be successful at engineering management.

session.title: Dungeons, Dragons, and Graph Databases
session.description:
Are you an adventurer? Do you want gold? Experience? Levels? Of course you do! And where do you get these things? The dungeon, where else? That wonderful container of all things adventurous! But, unfortunately, dungeons aren't setup for the convenience of adventurers who wish to extract these fine things. It’s almost as if the dungeon master just made the dungeon up at random. And so you wander about and you get what you get.

But you’re also a developer. You could build a database of all the rooms with their shiny and monstrous content. Then you could query it and find the optimal route to get the gold and the experience and the levels. But how would you model this data and write these queries? The rooms. The corridors. The monsters. The sparkling hoozits. That’s a lot of entities to relate to each other. And that’s gonna be a monster of a SQL query. Whoa–look at that JOIN! Better get my text editor ready.

Or, you could use a graph database. A graph database allows you to model these relationships simply and intuitively with nodes and edges. Being schema-free, you can evolve your graph as you encounter new things such as traps or secret doors. And, using the Cypher query language, you can write elegant and easy to understand queries that find the best routes to get the stuff adventures desire most.

In this talk, I’ll use the aforementioned example to introduce you to the concepts of graph databases. I’ll compare how to solve this problem with a relational database and how a graph database makes it easier. I’ll show you how to query and modify your graph. And, as no talk would be complete without a live demo, I’ll do it all using a real-time procedurally generated random dungeon (I am a dungeon master after all).

So come, have a flagon of mead as you learn about graph databases, optimize your dungeon crawl, and equip another weapon in your quest for better software!

session.title: Web for all. The power of progressive web apps
session.description: As web performance and user experience across both mobile and desktop devices continue to increase in importance, so do progressive web apps (PWAs). PWAs are becoming more popular because they have lots of enhancements that help your application perform better and they make apps accessible even to users with limited internet connection. In this talk, you are going to learn the advantages of using PWAs and how to turn your web application into a PWA.

session.title: Look Out, Redux! Here Comes NGXS!
session.description: NGXS brings Redux-like state management to Angular, but takes advantage of TypeScript to reduce the amount of boilerplate a programmer has to write. This session will introduce NGXS and its features, explain how it differs from Redux and why one might use it, followed by a look at a sample program. The speaker will provide some hints about using and debugging NGXS in the real world that were learned from using it at a project at a Fortune 500 company.

session.title: Using Chrome Developer Tools
session.description:
Chrome is not just a great browser for viewing websites, but also an invaluable tool for building websites. Out of the box, Chrome ships with “developers tools”. Many web developers are aware of this and make use of some of the tools it provides. However, most developers only scratch the surface of what the browser can do.

Join in as we take a deep dive into the Chrome developer tools and learn, among other things, how to:

– Quickly test styling fixes
– Emulate handheld devices to test responsive designs
– Easily navigate and debug JavaScript
– Use the JavaScript console
– View form submissions
– Monitor AJAX requests
– Check for performance issues
– Troubleshoot caching issues
– Create and use your own snippets

session.title: The Command Line - A Humble Journey
session.description:
Have you used the command line lately? Ever given much thought to how it came to be?

I'm not surprised - I haven't given it much thought either. But after learning more about the journey the CLI has taken to get us to where we are today, gives me a new appreciation, and understanding, of how the CLI works. Many of the things we do today are rooted in the past, and the CLI is no different. Sit back, relax, and enjoy the origin story of our old friend, the command line.

session.title: React Server Components with non-JS backends
session.description:
React Server Components are an exciting upcoming feature that makes it easy to deliver a faster and better web experience for your users. However, with the shift of React to the server, companies not already using Node.js on the backend may shy away from this technology and thus lose out on any of the benefits it brings.

But it is as not as difficult as it seems! In this presentation, I will show how you can use tools such as containers and code generation to make it easy for server components to interface with your backend of choice during both development and deployment.

session.title: Compose yourself! Different kinds of composition functions
session.description:
Composables can be simple or complex. They can be as simple as a logic gate or as complex as any renderless component, mixin, directive, or plugin.

From "useTimeout" to "useVirtualList", VueUse provides a collection of essential composition functions and renderless components.

In this session, we'll take a deep-dive into VueUse.

session.title: The Future of Front End Tooling is Here: Esbuild, Vite, Turbopack & Webpack
session.description: The front end build tooling landscape is changing rapidly.  Let's take a look at the new available technologies, and how they operate.  Then, we'll dive into migration concerns and even talk about leveraging some of this new tech within existing Webpack projects!

session.title: Why GraphQL is Perfect for Node.js Microservices
session.description: GraphQL and microservices architectures are perfectly compatible. You can use GraphQL as a data layer for Node.js microservices and combine data from all these services into one universal API. This way, you can break the core of your services into different microservices while still providing one endpoint that your clients can interact with. Before diving into GraphQL, let's explore what microservices are and why it can be helpful to add GraphQL.

session.title: Deceptive Patterns & FAST
session.description:
Deceptive patterns (also widely known as "dark patterns") are all over the Web. I'll speak to the accessibility impact deceptive patterns and "dark" patterns have as well as my introduction to taking these patterns and my work in the W3C to have these published in WCAG 3.

There is a lot of work being done in the Functional Needs group of the W3C to introduce these to FAST. I'll talk about FAST, what it means to accessibility, and to users, developers, designers, and everyone in-between in the organization.

I'll also introduce people to the Framework for Accessible Specification of Technologies (FAST) which advises creators of technical specifications on ensuring their technology meets the needs of users with disabilities. It primarily addresses web content technologies but also relates to any technology that affects web content sent to users, including client-side APIs, transmission protocols, and interchange formats. Specifications that implement these guidelines make it possible for content authors and user agents to render the content in an accessible manner to people with a wide range of abilities.

session.title: Progressive state management with Angular
session.description:
You’ve probably heard about NgRx, Redux, and other options for state management with Angular. Perhaps you considered those solutions but steered away from them because of the extra complexity and volume of code introduced by NgRx and Redux.
In this talk, Alain is going to explain the basics of how to manage your application state with Angular, as well as cover a more progressive approach to state management.
We will be talking about RxJs, Subjects, Observable Stores, and get into Ngrx Store as the ultimate step in our state management journey.

session.title: What does it takes to make a div?
session.description:
With the advent of frameworks, build tools, and deployment services, the distance between developers and browsers is growing. Developer Experience has improved, but with these abstractions, we've introduced layers of obscurity.

In this talk, we'll take a deep dive into what happens after you hit save. What processes take place to get your code transformed for production, how does it get deployed, and the steps required before a div can get to a user.

session.title: Afternoon Break
Use the Platform with Framework-Agnostic Routing
session.description:
Have you ever had to code logic for navigations, loading/mutating/reloading data, or request cancellations in your apps? Have you ever gotten it wrong? Let me show you a future where you can let the new Remix Router handle all of that for you - all while coding in the UI library of your choosing.

At Remix we're _stoked_ about nested + data-driven routing. The `loaders`/`actions` approach pioneered by the Remix framework has completely changed how we think about writing our applications. The days of render-driven waterfall data loads -- and all the spinners that come with it -- are over, and the resulting UX/DX is amazing. We're so excited about this approach that we didn't think it was fair to keep this limited to the React ecosystem. We realized early on that this was a Web (not React) problem that needed a Web (not React) solution

Let's walk through some of the problems with modern render/fetch-in-component approaches and look at how we can provide a much better experience for our users if we change the way we think about our application architecture. We'll look at the benefits of nested and data-driven routing, and the new framework-agnostic Remix Router driving React Router 6.4.0. We'll show how this router _vastly_ simplifies our mental model and reduces our application code, leading to better user experiences and fewer bugs! We gain this simplicity by embracing web standards and using things the browser already does _really_ well -- like handling forms, requests, and responses -- all while keeping the awesome UX provided by today's modern frameworks.

Finally, we'll look at how we can leverage the Remix Router in frameworks beyond React. You'll be amazed at how much framework-specific code disappears when you're delegating the majority of your routing, loading, and mutating logic to the Remix Router. Say goodbye to all those `useState/useEffects` (React) or those `ref/watchEffects` (Vue) and focus on writing your presentation layer in the library of your choice. So whether you're rocking with React, vibing with Vue, or all about that Angular - you can leverage the Remix Router to provide great experiences for your users.

session.title: AI in React.js
session.description: Want to see how easy it is to build a website with React?  Let's create a few websites live!  You'll understand the basics of AI, and more importantly you'll see how easy it is to come up with new ideas that have never been done before, and build them.  This talk is the comic book transformation from React developer to superhero.

session.title: If it ain’t broke, why fix it? AKA Migrating from $FRAMEWORK to Vue
session.description: The phrase “if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it” is something many of us have heard, especially when dealing with “legacy code.” In this talk, Kayla will talk about her experiences with moving a codebase from KnockoutJS to Vue. She’ll discuss the process of refactoring an application to modern JavaScript framework and potential strategies to mitigate technical debt along the way. She’ll also give you some talking points to help convince your boss to take development time away from adding new features to focus on upgrading the tech stack to something that’s easier to work with. Because if it ain’t broke, why should we fix it?

session.title: Accelerating Multi-tenant Full Stack Development with AWS Amplify
session.description: Learn how AWS Amplify can enable rapid development of React based full stack SaaS Application that enable the management and isolation of tenant users, a GraphQL integration with functions as a services, and options for NoSQL and Relational database storage.

session.title: What You Need to Know About the Edge
session.description: If you listen to the hype, everything is moving to the "edge!" First we started deploying our apps and assets there and now our functions are moving there and even our data is migrating there - all powered by JavaScript. If you're wondering how the edge applies to you and your app, this session will break it down. We'll cover what we mean by the edge and specific ways you can leverage edge functions and edge data to improve your application.

session.title: Pixel-Perfect Mockups and Other Disasters
session.description:
Designers and developers are both integral parts of delivering a functional software product. So why does it often feel like pulling teeth when the two need to cross paths? In this talk, I’ll dive into common pitfalls in the design to delivery hand-off, and why this really isn’t a hand-off at all.   

We’ll discuss why things like pixel-perfect mockups and separate design and development phases make the process harder than it needs to be. We'll also discuss why practices like the design sandwich and designer-developer pairing sessions lead to both better and faster results.

session.title: TBD
Common Accessibility Pitfalls: Climbing out, when you fall in.
session.description:
You, your users, and Alice from Wonderland have something in common. At one point, everyone has fallen into a hole of perplexity, confusion, and sometimes hysterical madness. Unlike Alice, we can navigate ourselves and our users around the chaotic abyss that we call the web. Shipping inaccessible experiences to our users can have unpleasant effects. Being cognizant of all the things that can go wrong and who are potential users are will take us farther along our journey.

In this session we are going to learn about common accessibility violations that surface when we are lackadaisical about the experiences we ship. We will cover semantic markup, alt attributes and images, color contrast, and more. Attendees will walk away able to identify these problem areas in their codebases and learning techniques, tools, and best practices to keep our users happy and not drive them mad.

session.title: The 7 Pillar Developer: Lifestyle Systems for the Exceptional Developer
session.description: To dramatically expand our potential as developers, we must reconsider our behaviors away from the keyboard, as humans. In this story-oriented session, we'll explore seven surprisingly relevant facets of life that profoundly impact our software quality: focus, systems thinking, psychology, communication, image, time management, and education.

session.title: Team Trivia and Conf reception!
session.description: Team Trivia and Conf reception!

sessions.title: Breakfast
Mentorship, or How to rebuild civilisation from scratch
sessions.description: How really important are mentorship and documentation to the survival of civilization? What would happen if we lost everything and had to start over, say, due to a global pandemic? In this talk, we'll explore my fascination with dystopian TV shows and seek to answer these questions, and come to some action steps to do our part through mentorship, documentation, and more.

sessions.title: Typescript Deep Dive
sessions.description: Mapped types, template literals, conditional types with infer: oh my! Come to this talk if you already understand how to use typescript day to day, but want to take a deeper dive and understand the more advanced topics in Typescript through real world examples and usecases.

sessions.title: Morning Break
Make Quick Angular, React or Vue Apps with VIte and JHipster Lite
sessions.description: We will spin up a basic application in minutes using JHipster Lite. Changing the front-end is a simple choice during app generation. Easily compare and contrast these js frameworks and learn with a real app instead of Hello World. We can even generate some back-end code if that is your jam.

sessions.title: Lunch
Building with SvelteKit
sessions.description:
Want to get familiar with the framework that took the top spot for most loved framework on the Stack Overflow developer survey in 2021?

Svelte is a super versatile framework with no virtual dom unlike React and Vue, it's a compiler that builds your projects into vanilla HTML, CSS and JavaScript.

This workshop will go over the basics of setting up with SvelteKit and querying data from a GraphQL API and using that data in SvelteKit to retrieve data for use in the client (browser).

In this workshop, you'll learn the basics of using Svelte to build a site that will get content from a GraphQL endpoint.
We'll be building a blog! Sorry, I know the blog is the new ToDo list but it's a great way to understand what we'll be covering in the workshop.

sessions.title: Afternoon Break
Debugging with JS Frameworks
sessions.description: Developers spend half their time debugging, but often don't have an effective process or understanding of debugging tools. JS frameworks like React, Angular, and Vue add to the complexity of debugging. This talk will break down an approach for JS Framework debugging, including how to use tools effectively to identify common patterns of bugs. Regardless of what framework you use or your level of debugging experience, this talk will help you debug more confidently.

sessions.title: Mega Raffle and Conf Close
Grab Dinner with your friends and see you at the after party!
sessions.description: Ask us for recommendations!

sessions.title: Conference After Party!
Building Serverless Applications and APIs with JavaScript and Microsoft Azure
sessions.description: Tired of spending money for cloud services you don't use? In this session, we will look at the products offered by Microsoft Azure for developing serverless web applications and APIs. This will also include the tooling offered by the Azure CLI and Visual Studio Code. Attendees will learn how to use JavaScript and TypeScript to integrate compute, data, AI and devops to create efficient and cost-effective apps. Note that all services discussed are available under a free Azure trial.

sessions.title: Managing Remote State in React
sessions.description: In most applications, there is some data stored in a remote location from your application. With remote state, there is data fetching logic that you have to write and reuse across your app. Moreover, after handling the logic, you have to deal with caching, deduplicating multiple requests, optimistic updates and more. In this talk, we will learn about React Query and how it helps us overcome the challenges of dealing with remote state.

sessions.title: Making your website stand out with React-Three-Fiber
sessions.description:
React-Three-Fiber is a React renderer for Three.js that leverages React's ecosystem and Declarative syntax to create reactive three-dimensional scenes in the browser 

In this talk, I'll show just how easy it is to get started with React-Three-Fiber to create professional looking 3D scenes and physics-based games, which can then used to create new browsing experiences and elevate existing applications.

sessions.title: Web Components x React: How it is and how it could be
sessions.description: In this talk, I will go over what Web Components are, who's using them, and the benefits. Then I will show how Web Components are implemented in React's current version and contrast that with how to do the same in an experimental branch with full support for Web Components.

sessions.title: Patterns for Large Scale Vue.js Applications
sessions.description:
What is the best way to structure a Vue.js application so that it can scale to meet all your users' needs? There are multiple patterns established by the Vue community and the programming community at large that can be adopted in order to make your codebases more predictable, maintainable, and extendable.

Vue can be used for large and small projects alike. Large scale projects though, need to be approached with a bit more thought and design. Why not be inspired by tried and true design patterns from the Vue.js community at large.

During the talk we discuss practical design patterns for making your large scale Vue.js projects more predictable including:

- Adopting community standards
- Component conventions
- Routing conventions
- Using sdks
- Wrapping third-party libs
- and more!

sessions.title: E Pluribus Vuenum: Break-up a massive Vue front-end & deploy it with an integration pipeline
sessions.description: In this talk, we’ll present a novel Vue architecture that incorporates multiple apps with their own repos and CI pipelines into a single SPA. We’ll demonstrate how we automated our deployment and integration testing to enable many contributors to work on disparate feature apps within a single front-end. A developer can merge a small change to their feature app and then, without further intervention, a new, fully tested version of the entire front-end will deploy to production a few minutes later.

sessions.title: What’s New with Nuxt 3
sessions.description: The release of Nuxt 3 is right around the corner. Are you ready? More importantly, is your project ready? A lot has changed during its development. In this session I will be discussing improvements, new features and what to expect from the 3.0 release of Nuxt.

sessions.title: Vue3 & Pinia: A better pattern for global state management
sessions.description: As a lover of all things Vue & Vuex for many years, I was very excited to welcome the advent of Pinia as the new defacto global state management tool for the Vue ecosystem.  Pinia builds upon the lessons learned from the Vuex era, and introduces a few important changes to how we leverage global state in our apps.  In this talk, we'll go over those key differences, and then I'll share some of my thoughts on how I approach global state, when to reach for it and why it can set you up for success when scaling your codebase.

sessions.title: Beyond Test-Driven Development
sessions.description:
Test-Driven Development (TDD) is a simple three-step practice. Its practitioners claim they regularly deliver higher-quality code in less time. But... what if there were a better way?

In this session, you'll learn to avoid the limitations caused by the way TDD is usually taught. You'll also learn to avoid the most common problems developers have with writing automated tests, and how to leverage the process to minimize the time spent debugging... which leaves you more time for the fun parts.

sessions.title: Deploying on Google Cloud: a Guide for People Who Despise Deploying
sessions.description: While some of us delight in the process of getting code out to the end users, not everyone feels that joy. Join me to learn the easy way to let GCP do the work for you!

sessions.title: Design patterns for modern JavaScript
sessions.description: The IE11 winter is over! While we were hibernating, JavaScript evolved dramatically — yet most of our design patterns haven’t. Developers (yes, you) — it’s time to refresh how we author our “everyday code” and leverage these new tools! This talk will discuss new patterns for creating a global store, memoizing instance data, emitting events, parsing strings, and observing DOM elements. The future of JavaScript is already here — we just need to learn how to use it.

sessions.title: Open-Sourced - Growth Hacking Your Tech Skills
sessions.description:
How does one grow one's technical skills on limited resources ( whether by choice or otherwise ) or show how one can learn using current resources?

This talk aims to provide a how-to guide to developing one's technical skills using community resources to enhance the developer's journey. It will use examples from my journey such as freeCodeCamp meetups, mentorships, hackathons, and civic hacking, providing actionable steps with accompanying learned insights.  These steps include : 
=> What is is open source learning?
=> Establishing your learning goal and breaking down the steps to getting there. 
=> Understanding the importance of joining a community and being an active participant. 
=> Why you should blog and tweet your progress as you learn.
=> Why and how you should contribute to open source?
=> How to find activities such as hackathons, meetups, and civic hacking groups that will challenge you?
=> Examine how to building a coding habit eg #100daysofCode. 
=> How using open source resources helps you to learn makes you a better and more valuable developer/ engineer. 
=> Etc ( anything else that may cater to the theme of the conference or meetup where this talk is being given).

sessions.title: Migrating from REST to GraphQL
sessions.description: Are you ready to start using GraphQL but don’t have time to rewrite your legacy REST API? In this session, we’ll show you some strategies for incrementally porting your APIs to start using GraphQL that allows you to leverage your existing REST APIs.

sessions.title: Functional Web Apps - The revenge of dynamic web apps
sessions.description: Building static websites with a Jamstack approach offers a fantastic solution for building massively available systems without the downsides of traditional dynamic stacks like Rails, Express or Wordpress. But there is a different way. In this talk you will learn how to build massively available dynamic web apps with pure cloud functions. Functional Web Apps (FWA) are built with pure cloud functions, sport a builtin database and deploy quickly and reliably. No more waiting on slow builds. No more trading off a dynamic end user experience by pre-rendering spinners. We will build markup on the fly with the determinism and reliability of immutable deployments leveraging the power and simplicity of the ultimate building block: pure cloud functions.

sessions.title: Tailwind CSS: A Different Approach to Styling Websites
sessions.description: Using a prescribed CSS framework like Bootstrap can help you quickly build websites, but when you need more control and want to leverage your CSS skills, Tailwind CSS provides a different approach. In this talk, Shawn Wildermuth will show you how Tailwind CSS is a different way to style your websites.

sessions.title: What the Heck is Edge Computing Anyway?
sessions.description:
The Edge is the new frontier of computing possibilities, offering promises, opportunities, and it’s own set of challenges. In this talk, we’ll break down what it is, why it’s awesome, and how it fits into your application architecture.

We’ll cover things like:
- What are the benefits 
- What are the limitations 
- When it makes sense 
- When it doesn’t make sense 
- How to get started

sessions.title: Mining Electronic Documents for Fun and Profit (and other business critical needs)
sessions.description: Some estimates put the number of PDFs in the world at nearly three trillion. While having information in a digital format makes them much safer and easier to store, it still represents a challenge. How do we know what's in a PDF? How can we organize and process our documents in an efficient manner? How can we check for potentially problematic text that should be updated? In this talk, I'll talk about how the Adobe PDF Extract API can be used to mine information from your documents and how this can be combined with NLP (Natural Language Processing) from Microsoft to help truly get a grip on what's in your document store.

sessions.title: Small Design Systems for Developers
sessions.description: There has been a lot of movement in the industry about Design Systems, and sometimes reading about them I feel overwhelmed by how large they seem to get. So this talk is about small design systems, and how they can help your workflow as a developer, and how to solve certain real world problems with tooling for design tokens.

sessions.title: Designing Real-time Web Applications
sessions.description:
Near-real-time web applications have become increasingly common with advancements in event-driven server-side systems, websockets, and Javascript frameworks. Gone are the days of the user having to mash the refresh button to see updates to data that frequently changes. As a product development team, you can now send near-real-time updates to every user on your site about every change that happens... but should you?

In this talk, we’ll cover some of the practical design questions we’ve learned to consider when deciding how and when to notify users of changes as well as how to handle things when the connection breaks. When the session ends, you’ll have some ideas from real-world examples to ensure your users get the Goldilocks experience... not so much that it overwhelms them, not so little so that they're making decisions on stale data, but just the right amount of timely information.

sessions.title: How Social Media Can Land You Your Dream Job
sessions.description: Networking pre-covid was awkward...let's face it. It was showing up to a meetup or a conference and you only hung out with the few people you knew. You watched 45 slides on a topic that you don't understand only to leave the session and be even more confused. You then leave the networking event almost feeling worse than before (it maybe was the pizza) AND you didn't meet anyone new. Well, networking has changed especially because of Covid. In this session, I dig into how to build your LinkedIn profile where it gets attention from recruiters and hiring managers.  I also go over how to ACTUALLY network virtually on LinkedIn. After this session, you should feel very good on how to leverage this platform to connect with individuals! If you are an introvert...this session is for you!

sessions.title: TBD
Facade Pattern with NgRx
sessions.description: Do you or other developers on your team struggle with NgRx actions and reducers? Does it make implementing new features difficult? In this talk, we will discuss the Facade Pattern with NgRx and the benefits of implementing them together. I will dive into how reactive state management works within Angular. Then I will show you why implementing the facade pattern to decouple your state management from your components is a good idea.

sessions.title: Scully: The Angular Static Site Is Out There
sessions.description: Angular is a powerful web application framework that helps us build impressive enterprise applications, but as static "Jamstack" sites grow in popularity, those who maintain Angular apps may feel the grass is greener with other technologies that are optimized for faster page rendering. Fortunately, the open source tool Scully is a static site generator that works with Angular to pre-render content and deliver fast and secure websites that can still connect to APIs to render dynamic content as needed. In this talk, I will demonstrate Scully by showing how it can be added to an existing Angular project, explain how it actually works behind the scenes to produce the new static assets, and recommend some good practices for incrementally improving your Angular applications.

sessions.title: This is why you should [always] use the Async Pipe
sessions.description:
The Async Pipe has transcended the legend status in the Angular realm and has become a mythical tool for newcomers. It unpacks so much that the magical aura surrounding it seems justified. 
In this session though, we will unfortunately have to challenge the myth with our detective goggles and reveal all the underlying greatness that make it our no brainer choice in dealing with observables, subcriptions or promises.

sessions.title: Accessibility Can Streamline Your Front End Process
sessions.description: Starting with accessibility when building user interfaces can simplify your decision making, and streamline your overall front-end development process. We'll look at how to recognize good and bad practices for accessibility with examples in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Then we'll see how those practices relate to a more robust, maintainable, and testable end result for your team over the long term. Finally we'll take a quick tour of some resources you can use to start focusing on accessibility in your own work.

sessions.title: Flexbox + CSS Grid = Awesome!
sessions.description:
The traditional 'box' layout model was designed to layout documents, not apps. Many hours have been lost endlessly tinkering with the positioning of HTML elements, but the joy at achieving perfect alignment is short-lived. Everything looks great until the page is loaded on a mobile device, and it looks like you threw things on a page from across the room. There's a better way! 
In this talk I will teach you about the flexbox layout model and CSS grid. We will cover these concepts at a high level, discuss why they are a better approach, and I will show you how to use them effectively. Used in tandem, these widely supported techniques can make your pages responsive, more accessible, and easier to build.

sessions.title: Let’s web dev like it’s 1999!
sessions.description:
When we “view source” our modern web applications, the code looks nothing like what we originally wrote. At a minimum, it’s gone through linting, transpilation, obfuscation, minification, and bundling. And in order to build our beautifully designed apps with sophisticated interactions, we leverage the latest features in HTML, CSS and JavaScript available in our modern evergreen browsers.

However, when web development was in its infancy two decades ago, things were drastically different. Sites had hit counters, used frames for navigation, and were updated manually via FTP. We used the blink tag and scrolling marquees! Let’s take a walk down memory lane (or have a history lesson) and have some laughs cringing at how sites looked, how they were built, and the rudimentary tooling we had to develop them.

sessions.title: Turn Your Static Site Up to Eleven(ty)
sessions.description:
Eleventy.js is a static site generator (and meant as an alternative to Jekyll), written purely in Javascript, which lets you create websites with easy to modify content. A classic use case would be a company landing page, a personal site, or documentation for a project.

Eleventy by itself is powerful. When you combine it with hosting providers (such as Netlify), a headless CMS (such as Ghost), or the new generation of static site hosts (like CloudCannon), it lets you superpower your development without needing to be an expert at Wordpress.

We'll look at how Eleventy projects work, strengths and weaknesses relative to other types of site generators, and how you can use Eleventy to build really excellent sites.

session.title: Breakfast
Mentorship, or How to rebuild civilisation from scratch
session.description: How really important are mentorship and documentation to the survival of civilization? What would happen if we lost everything and had to start over, say, due to a global pandemic? In this talk, we'll explore my fascination with dystopian TV shows and seek to answer these questions, and come to some action steps to do our part through mentorship, documentation, and more.

session.title: Typescript Deep Dive
session.description: Mapped types, template literals, conditional types with infer: oh my! Come to this talk if you already understand how to use typescript day to day, but want to take a deeper dive and understand the more advanced topics in Typescript through real world examples and usecases.

session.title: Building Serverless Applications and APIs with JavaScript and Microsoft Azure
session.description: Tired of spending money for cloud services you don't use? In this session, we will look at the products offered by Microsoft Azure for developing serverless web applications and APIs. This will also include the tooling offered by the Azure CLI and Visual Studio Code. Attendees will learn how to use JavaScript and TypeScript to integrate compute, data, AI and devops to create efficient and cost-effective apps. Note that all services discussed are available under a free Azure trial.

session.title: Patterns for Large Scale Vue.js Applications
session.description:
What is the best way to structure a Vue.js application so that it can scale to meet all your users' needs? There are multiple patterns established by the Vue community and the programming community at large that can be adopted in order to make your codebases more predictable, maintainable, and extendable.

Vue can be used for large and small projects alike. Large scale projects though, need to be approached with a bit more thought and design. Why not be inspired by tried and true design patterns from the Vue.js community at large.

During the talk we discuss practical design patterns for making your large scale Vue.js projects more predictable including:

- Adopting community standards
- Component conventions
- Routing conventions
- Using sdks
- Wrapping third-party libs
- and more!

session.title: Morning Break
Make Quick Angular, React or Vue Apps with VIte and JHipster Lite
session.description: We will spin up a basic application in minutes using JHipster Lite. Changing the front-end is a simple choice during app generation. Easily compare and contrast these js frameworks and learn with a real app instead of Hello World. We can even generate some back-end code if that is your jam.

session.title: Managing Remote State in React
session.description: In most applications, there is some data stored in a remote location from your application. With remote state, there is data fetching logic that you have to write and reuse across your app. Moreover, after handling the logic, you have to deal with caching, deduplicating multiple requests, optimistic updates and more. In this talk, we will learn about React Query and how it helps us overcome the challenges of dealing with remote state.

session.title: Lunch
Building with SvelteKit
session.description:
Want to get familiar with the framework that took the top spot for most loved framework on the Stack Overflow developer survey in 2021?

Svelte is a super versatile framework with no virtual dom unlike React and Vue, it's a compiler that builds your projects into vanilla HTML, CSS and JavaScript.

This workshop will go over the basics of setting up with SvelteKit and querying data from a GraphQL API and using that data in SvelteKit to retrieve data for use in the client (browser).

In this workshop, you'll learn the basics of using Svelte to build a site that will get content from a GraphQL endpoint.
We'll be building a blog! Sorry, I know the blog is the new ToDo list but it's a great way to understand what we'll be covering in the workshop.

session.title: Making your website stand out with React-Three-Fiber
session.description:
React-Three-Fiber is a React renderer for Three.js that leverages React's ecosystem and Declarative syntax to create reactive three-dimensional scenes in the browser 

In this talk, I'll show just how easy it is to get started with React-Three-Fiber to create professional looking 3D scenes and physics-based games, which can then used to create new browsing experiences and elevate existing applications.

session.title: What’s New with Nuxt 3
session.description: The release of Nuxt 3 is right around the corner. Are you ready? More importantly, is your project ready? A lot has changed during its development. In this session I will be discussing improvements, new features and what to expect from the 3.0 release of Nuxt.

session.title: Afternoon Break
Debugging with JS Frameworks
session.description: Developers spend half their time debugging, but often don't have an effective process or understanding of debugging tools. JS frameworks like React, Angular, and Vue add to the complexity of debugging. This talk will break down an approach for JS Framework debugging, including how to use tools effectively to identify common patterns of bugs. Regardless of what framework you use or your level of debugging experience, this talk will help you debug more confidently.

session.title: Web Components x React: How it is and how it could be
session.description: In this talk, I will go over what Web Components are, who's using them, and the benefits. Then I will show how Web Components are implemented in React's current version and contrast that with how to do the same in an experimental branch with full support for Web Components.

session.title: Mega Raffle and Conf Close
Grab Dinner with your friends and see you at the after party!
session.description: Ask us for recommendations!

session.title: Conference After Party!
